awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The ecological context of early ape evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation project examines the early diversification of apes within the broader context of mammalian community evolution. Leveraging rich fossil collections, the investigators characterize mammal assemblages from multiple, well-studied localities to examine how time, space and environmental factors impacted mammalian community structure. The scientific importance of this project lies in providing a comparative backdrop of mammalian evolution to better understand the ecological setting for major adaptations in the ape and human lineage. More broadly, this project can have significant impacts for science and society by expanding participation in science through graduate training and research opportunities for undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in STEM research. A relational database of paleontological data assembled through this project is planned for public distribution to scientists and educators via the Data Repository at the University of Minnesota (DRUM). Other results will be made available through peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and public outreach opportunities aimed at providing scientific engagement at public schools and museums. 

The early divergence of ape lineages, during which several major adaptive characteristics of the ape-human clade were established, is primarily recorded in the early Miocene (ca. 23-16 Ma). Although fossil apes from this time have been the subject of intense study, little work has been done to properly situate the diversity of these species within the broader context of mammalian community evolution. This project asks the central question: how did environment, time, and geographic distance influence the structure of early Miocene mammalian communities? Using large fossil assemblages, this project pursues four specific questions: 1) do fossil assemblages from major collecting areas represent differences in mammalian community structure? 2) do changes in mammalian community structure track environmental differences inferred from associated paleoecological proxies? 3) are mammalian community structures most similar among assemblages that are closest in age? and 4) does similarity in mammalian community structure decrease with increasing geographic distance between assemblages? These questions are addressed by analyzing the mammalian community structure across 13 fossil localities that are already well-characterized in terms of age and paleoenvironment. By situating mammalian community succession within temporal, geographic, and environmental contexts, this project can inform our understanding of how these factors influenced changes among mammal species, thereby clarifying the ecological parameters within which major adaptations in the ape and human lineage arose.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
The ecological context in which early apes evolved remains a critical unresolved question in paleoanthropology. This project, “The ecological context of early ape evolution”, analysed mammalian community structure at several Kisingiri fossil localities on Mfangano Island and Rusinga Island, Kenya, to better situate the largest sample of early apes within a broader framework of mammalian community succession, and, importantly, to calibrate these community structures according to changes in time, space, and habitat. New research indicates the Early Miocene Kisingiri sequence provides a unique opportunity to study change in mammalian communities over nearly three million years within a single geological sequence. High resolution, multi-proxy paleoenvironmental data are also now available for the main fossiliferous localities in this sequence, making it possible to frame faunal and paleoenvironmental data within a long-term chronology to assess how specific ecological factors impact mammalian communities’ over time. This project asked the central question: How did environment, time and geographic distance influence the structure of Early Miocene mammalian communities?

 

This project facilitated the creation of a relational database containing several types of data from 17,651 mammalian fossil specimens from Rusinga and Mfangano Islands. These specimens represent all mammalian fossils collected there and stored at the National Museums of Kenya and the Natural History Museum, London. The data recorded in the database for each specimen include geological provenance, morphological identification , taphonomic details, taxonomic attribution, collection history, identification history, publication history, relevant measurements, and storage location. The long temporal span and massive fossil assemblages of Rusinga and Mfangano make these collections a touchstone for understanding Early Miocene African mammals, and especially catarrhines (Old World monkeys and apes). Matching these assemblages with high-resolution paleoecological and geochronological data has created an invaluable resource for numerous researchers working on fossils from the Miocene. Compiling data from all of these specimens into a database has enhanced the utility of the results of this project and allows for future emendations and additions to be easily made. This database will be shared with the National Museums of Kenya for research use once the results of this project have been published.

 

Mammalian community structure was represented in the project by measures of species composition, richness and abundance, and body size representation, and abundance. Statistical methods were used to explore relationships among the Mfangano and Rusinga assemblages and to test specific hypotheses related to the central question. Overall, the results suggest that both time and environment played crucial roles in shaping the Early Miocene mammalian communities. Results further suggest that the oldest assemblages in the Kisingiri sequence, from Mfangano, more closely resemble other Early Miocene Kenyan localities rather than younger Kisingiri localities on Rusinga. Specifically, the structure of the mammalian community from localities on Mfangano suggests the Mfangano fauna as a whole is derived from at least two distinct time periods; the oldest being similar to other Early Miocene Kenyan localities in the Tinderet sequence and the youngest occupying an intermediate position between the Tinderet localities and the younger localities on Rusinga. Interesting results were also found in the Rusinga assemblages indicating that differences in the structure of the mammalian communities across localities on Rusinga track differences in both age and environment of the localities. For example, there are clear differences in the abundance structure of specific rodent species and hoofed mammal species between the oldest, intermediate, and youngest Rusinga localities. Additionally, differences in the mammalian communities at the localities R1, R3, R106, and R5 on Rusinga reflect differences in the paleoenvironmental reconstructions of those localities. Results of this project better situate the largest sample of Early Miocene apes within a broader framework of mammalian community succession and facilitate our understanding of how specific ecological conditions impacted the evolution of apes. The results of this project improve our understanding of how specific ecological conditions experienced by all mammals impacted the early evolution of the ape-human clade.

 

This award allowed the Co-PI Hall to gain critical experience while examining fossil mammal collections and comparative skeletal collections; gain experience necessary to become an expert in identifying and classifying fossil specimens in terms of taxonomy and morphology; learn statistical methods for data analysis; gain experience managing and creating a large multivariate database; and build long term collaborative relationships with domestic and international researchers. Results from this project were presented at the 2024 North American Paleontology Convention, the 2024 Society of Vertebrate Paleontology Annual Meeting, and the 2025 American Association of Biological Anthropology Annual Meeting. This project will result in the publication of at least four peer-reviewed scientific articles in relevant academic journals, such as the Journal of Human Evolution, the American Journal of Biological Anthropology, and the Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology.

 


Last Modified: 03/19/2025
Modified by: Kieran P McNulty
